trial_identification.studytitle: Randomised control trial of adductor canal block versus intra-articular catheter in knee replacement surgery
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In total knee replacement surgery does an adductor canal block or intra-articular catheter with infusions give superior analgesia and range of movement

interventions.interventions:
Adductor canal block versus intra-articular catheter for pain relief in total knee replacement surgery. (Both treatments are given in addition to standard anaesthetic care)
Group Adductor canal block Ultrasound guided injection into adductor canal to administer block of femoral nerve at this level of 20ml 0.375% ropivacaine with 8mg dexamethasone. Administered once only immediately prior to surgery.
interventions.comparator: Group intra-articular catheter (Both treatments are given in addition to standard anaesthetic care) 10ml 0.75% ropivacaine with 1mcg adrenaline and 30mg ketorolac infused via intra-articular catheter infusion immediately after closure of the wound during surgery and in addition at 24 and 36 hours post operatively.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The primary endpoints are -a clinically and statistically significant difference in pain as measured by a visual analogue scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: daily for the first 3 days then on discharge day at 2 week follow up at 6 weeks at 3 months at 6 months post operatively

primaryOutcome.outcome: - a clinically and statistically significant difference in range of movement of the operated knee measured by goniometer in degrees.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: daily for the first 3 days then on discharge day at 2 week follow up at 6 weeks at 3 months at 6 months post operatively

secondaryOutcome.outcome: - a clinically and statistically significant difference in scores on the Oxford knee score
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre-operatively and then at 2 week follow up at 6 weeks at 3 months and at 6 months post operatively

secondaryOutcome.outcome: -Use of breakthrough analgesia as measured by doses of patient controlled analgesia administered / use of PRN analgesia.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: daily for the first 3 days then on discharge day at 2 week follow up at 6 weeks at 3 months at 6 months post operatively

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Undergoing Total knee replacement Able to consent to inclusion in study
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Unable to consent to inclusion in study Allergy to trial medications

trial_design.concealment: Allocation will be conducted in a concealed fashion by sealed opaque envelopes.

recruitment.hospital: St John of God Hospital, Murdoch - Murdoch

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Participation will involve being randomly assigned to one of two routinely used pain management protocols to provide pain relief in the period immediately after total knee replacement surgery. Participants will be unaware as to which group they are in. A pain specialist doctor and nurse will assess pain control and range of movement of the knee at regular intervals following the surgery. This will assist surgeons and anaesthetists to determine the most effective regimen for future patients.
